On Tue, 23 Jul 2002, dph_of_rules wrote:

> Hey, I'm still interested in hearing everybody's reponse to that
> question.

Allrighty, I'll talk. The year was 1996 (maybe a few years earlier), and
me and a friend of mine downloaded Gladiator off of AOL's share/freeware
downloads. It joined the C:\Games directory with other titles such as
Quest for Glory 1, Hubie, Civilization 1, Skyroads, Commander Keen:
Goodbye Galaxy, and about a hundred other old old games. However, this was
the only game we had that was comfortably multiplayer, *and* you could
make levels! We played it religiously for about a month (instead of doing
homework and such :-) and got to the unregistered death level several
times. After one of those times we finally decided to fork over our life
savings and buy the registered version. I was young and naiive then, so I
downloaded it onto a floppy which turned out to be corrupt. After 30 mins
on the phone with whoever I ordered it from (I think Albert's Amby), they
sent me a copy via email.

For some reason I never knew about the registered password and stuff
untill now, though.

Anyways, comfortable single-comp multiplayer and a level editor was what
made it great, along with great gameplay and story. It was the first game
I saw with those features.

- Zardus
